bioghist.head: Biography
bioghist.p: The Henry Whitfield State Museum, established by the State of Connecticut in 1899, explores four centuries of Connecticut history through the evolution of the 1639 Whitfield House. Thirty-two years after the founding of Jamestown and nineteen years after the Pilgrims landed at Plymouth, a group of English Puritans journeyed across the Atlantic Ocean to establish a community in the New World free from religious persecution. They were led by their minister, Reverend Henry Whitfield. The Whitfield family home also served as a fort for the community. Its massive stone walls and chimneys, steeply-pitched roof, and casement windows reflect the style of post-medieval domestic architecture found in England - rare in 17th-century America and unique today. Through the years, the "Old Stone House" has undergone many changes and many families have called it home. Restored by noted architects Norman Isham and J. Frederick Kelly in the early 1900s, the house is an important example of Colonial Revival restoration work. Based on these restorations, the Whitfield House was designated a National Historic Landmark. The museum and library collections number over 10,000 items.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content of Collection
scopecontent.p: Primary and secondary source materials related to Guilford Native Americans and African Americans.
Deeds of sale - 1713 purchase of Bocha ('Carolina Indian Man') by Samuel Scranton and 1746 purchase of Phillis ('about Ten Years of Age') by Charles Caldwell
Guilford town records (including town expenses) from 1791 and 1809-1810
Merchant ledgers - 3 volumes ranging in date (1721-1828) referencing Candace, Edward, Nat, Ephraim Boyd, and Eliza Dublin
The Bill of Mortality (listing of deaths in Guilford, 1746-1840, with several entries marked 'Indian' or 'Negro')
1874 poem 'Old Shem's Prayer' by William Russel Dudley
1883 application to Guilford's Parmelee Post No. 42 of the Grand Army of the Republic for Richard Armstrong
Published war service records (American Revolution and Civil War)

Miscellaneous published histories, including 'The Quinnipiacs' by John Menta (2003), 'Catalogue of Relics' (1889), 'Yester-Years of Guilford' by Mary Hoadley Griswold (1938), 'Old Guilford' by Charles Daniel Hubbard (1961), 'Voices from North Guilford' (2012)

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: In general, the materials are stored by format and size and arranged by subject.
